channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Japan lost its climate leadership – and now Australia can help
item.description: Japan’s largest supplier of coal and LNG has just pledged to transition from fossil fuels – creating both tension and opportunity.

item.title: Republicans Criticize Hegseth for Deadly Caribbean Double Strike
item.description: Bipartisan lawmakers are demanding congressional probes into the defense secretary’s handling of a deadly boat strike.

item.title: Netanyahu Just Admitted He’s Unfit to Lead Israel
item.description: In attempting to call off his corruption trial, Netanyahu didn’t incriminate himself, but he did something just as damning.

item.title: Australia bets on old laws to manage new AI risks
item.description: Relying on legacy laws may seem pragmatic, but other countries are racing ahead with purpose-built AI regulation.

item.title: Deadly Fire Highlights Hong Kong’s Predicament
item.description: The tragedy confirmed to many locals that the city’s freedoms have vanished.

item.title: Trump’s Favorite Role? Foreign-Policy Czar.
item.description: In diplomacy, the U.S. president always seems to follow his own transactional view of human affairs.

item.title: Putin’s Threats Against Europe Undermine Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Moscow remains opposed to surrendering its territorial ambitions.

item.title: Putin Meets With Witkoff, Kushner to Discuss Ukraine Peace Plan
item.description: Moscow remains opposed to surrendering its territorial ambitions.

item.title: Trumpworld thinks Europe has betrayed the West
item.description: Centrist governments across the continent rightly sense a trap

item.title: The Minerals That Drive Trump’s Global Agenda
item.description: From Canada to Pakistan, an interest in critical minerals is a through line in the White House’s foreign policy.

item.title: AIs could turn opinion polls into gibberish
item.description: Large language models can answer surveys and pass the tests to check that a respondent is human

item.title: Trump’s Venezuela Fixation Is Not About the Oil
item.description: There are lots of reasons why the Trump administration is angling for regime change in Caracas, but heavy oil isn’t one of them.

item.title: Renminbi Internationalization Is Closing the Climate Finance Gap
item.description: Through a trifecta of fast-growing markets for renminbi-denominated bonds, China is showing that it can support domestic sustainability projects across the Global South. With the United States and other traditional creditors stepping back, Chinese finance is filling the vacuum.

item.title: Chris Waller, not Kevin Hassett, should lead the Federal Reserve
item.description: President Trump is about to make the wrong appointment

item.title: Ahead of peace talks, Russia’s battlefield advances remain slow
item.description: Even at an accelerated recent pace, seizing Ukraine’s eastern regions would take more than two years

item.title: ADB’s Emphasis on Critical Minerals Sparks Fear in Philippines
item.description: The ADB’s new program fits right into the Philippine government’s plans for transition mining – to the detriment of Indigenous communities.

item.title: Can Pakistan Adapt to Climate Disaster?
item.description: Three years ago, the country became a poster child for climate justice. Now, it faces a steep learning curve to secure the funding it needs.

item.title: 5 Chinese Workers Killed in 2 Attacks in Tajikistan Along Afghan Border
item.description: In one of the attacks, a drone was reportedly used to drop grenades on Chinese workers.

item.title: A Just Transition for Land
item.description: Annual economic losses linked to desertification, land degradation, and drought amount to $878 billion – far more than the investments needed to mitigate their impact. Only by using innovative financing mechanisms and collaborating more effectively can a just transition to a sustainable and resilient land economy be achieved.

item.title: High stakes in India’s refusal to send former Bangladesh PM to trial
item.description: A carefully worded extradition treaty means New Delhi can hedge its bets, but it should be prepared for blowback.

item.title: Creative Destruction Should Not Spare Commercial Banks
item.description: New technologies offer new opportunities to revamp payment and credit systems, making them not only more efficient but also safer. It would be a shame if these were foregone because banks believe that they have a right to a business model that they inherited from political compromises struck centuries ago.

item.title: Australia’s National AI Plan Has Just Been Released. Who Exactly Will Benefit?
item.description: The plan’s primary goal seems to be attracting international data center investment – even at the cost of abandoning regulation.

item.title: India-China Engage in War of Words Over Arunachal Pradesh
item.description: Chinese officials detained an Indian national for 18 hours at Shanghai airport, claiming that her Indian passport was not valid as she is from Arunachal Pradesh.

item.title: How a 42-year-old Massacre Is Returning to Roil Assam’s Politics
item.description: The long-suppressed Tiwari Commission report on the 1983 Nellie massacre has finally been released, but early responses suggest it may ignite debate on demographic change rather than accountability for one of India’s deadliest episodes of mass violence.

item.title: The Latest Earthquake Was a Warning Sign: Bangladesh Isn’t Ready
item.description: The recent M5.5 earthquake occurred outside the better known seismic hazard zones and is a wake-up call to boost preparedness.

item.title: Can America Win the New Race for Scientific Leadership?
item.description: Even as China and the United States compete for scientific leadership, the Trump administration has slashed investment in research and tightened immigration rules. If the US has truly entered a second Cold War, it should repeat the strategy that helped it win the first one: expanding the scientific frontier at home.

item.title: Toy Seller’s Legal Battle Shines Spotlight on China’s Ultra Strict Gun Rules
item.description: A merchant selling “gel blasters” is the latest person to face serious criminal charges for possession of seemingly harmless guns.

item.title: Why Is the PPP Still Defending Yoon Suk-yeol?
item.description: A year after the illegitimate declaration of martial law, the conservative People Power Party is still justifying Yoon’s decision.

item.title: Turkic or Central Asian? Azerbaijan’s Entry Tests the Region’s Identity
item.description: What, exactly, is “Central Asia” today?

item.title: How Taiwan Views the China-Japan Spat
item.description: A war of perceptions over framings of Japanese Prime Minister Takaichi is taking shape in Taiwan.

item.title: America is foolishly waving goodbye to thousands of Chinese boffins
item.description: Hostile policies and attacks on science are driving them back into China’s arms

item.title: Deeper into the Public Procurement Goldmine
item.description: Public procurement is one of the world’s most powerful yet underused industrial-policy tools. Rather than treating procurement as a routine administrative task, policymakers must harness it to guide innovators toward developing and scaling solutions to complex societal challenges, from infrastructure to climate resilience.

item.title: Why China Did Not Do a ‘Kissinger’ to Split Europe From America
item.description: Europe would have given almost anything for peace, but Beijing had a different calculus.

item.title: The G20 Must Follow Through on Debt Relief
item.description: Governments across Africa, Asia, and Latin America have been forced to cut spending on education, health care, and infrastructure to keep funds flowing to foreign creditors, undermining global stability and prosperity. To break this vicious cycle, G20 leaders must urgently revamp the Common Framework for Debt Treatment.

item.title: Malaysia’s Borneo Election Spells Trouble for Anwarjos
item.description: “Sabah for Sabahans” undermines the country’s precarious ethno-political balance.

item.title: Why the Pakistan Army Can’t Afford to Eliminate Imran Khan
item.description: Eliminating the immensely popular leader would not end the crisis; it would unleash one that the Pakistani state may not survive.

item.title: Want to fix Defence? Start by cutting bureaucratic bloat
item.description: Same people, same jobs, new structure – but somehow performance will improve. This story has been told before.

item.title: The Promise—and Limits—of a Free Press
item.description: Journalists alone cannot stave off autocracy.

item.title: The West’s Last Chance
item.description: How to build a new global order before it’s too late.

item.title: Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami’s 5-hour Work Plan for Women: A Patriarchal Ploy?
item.description: Many Bangladeshis believe that this is a strategy of the Jamaat to send working women back home.

item.title: Thailand Extradites Prominent Montagnard Rights Activist to Vietnam
item.description: The extradition of Y Quynh Bdap, 33, is a sign of a growing crackdown on Vietnamese refugees and asylum seekers in Thailand, rights groups say.

item.title: Changes to Brunei’s Land Ownership Laws Stoke Concerns, Uncertainty
item.description: Non-citizens, including established ethnic Chinese families, face the downgrade of freehold titles – some inherited over generations – into 30-to-60-year leases.
